151336169.review:
JUEGAZO
Lo recomiendo 10/10.

APRECIACIÓN
El juego se pasa en 2 horas y media aprox. El juego, en cuanto a escenario gráfico, es lo más bonito que vas a ver en un videojuego. Realizado por ilustradores, y músicos en un proyecto muy "indi". El juego no es difícil, aunque en ocasiones suponga pequeños retos (nada difícil para "gamers"). Ideal para jugar con la pareja.

¿DE QUÉ TRATA? 
Es un juego que aborda el tema de la depresión. En él se ve como la protagonista pierde la voz y el color de la vida por X motivo (se ve en la cinemática oculta que avanzo más adelante sin spoilear en la explicación de cómo conseguirla). En el avance de la historia veremos cómo nos cuesta andar al principio, veremos fases de reaida, alti-bajos, cómo vamos recuperando los colores de la vida según avanzamos en las fases del duelo (literalmente están los logros de las 5 fases del duelo), también veremos cómo nos enfrentamos a nuestros miedos internos, etc. Es una pasada.

RECOMENDACIÓN: 
Jugar con cascos este juego y con la luz apagada, si tenéis un ambilight en la tele mejor. El sonido funciona con 5.1 y 5.2.
Yo lo he jugado con un proyector a 110 pulgadas y con el sistema de sonido 5.2. 
Si tenéis la posibilidad (porque seáis unos frikis como nosotros), hacedlo.


Yo me lo he pasado 2 veces, y se lo voy a regalar a un par de amigos/as.

English / Chinese version available
该评论有 英文 / 中文 两个版本


English:
This game has one critical problem:
Just 2 dollars... Too cheap... (Laugh)

Update:
After I finished this game, I read some negative reviews. Most of them say this game is boring... I have to point it out here that in some ways, that's true... Despite GRIS has gorgeous art design, I have to confess that sometimes the gameplay is tedious, especially at the beginning of this game... In this game, what you can do is only jump, run, or press K or L... No attack, no boss fight, you'll never die, because there is no HP... Oh this game even doesn't need the mouse...
So, generally, If you just want to relax yourself, it's okay. But if you want a thrilling game, GRIS may let you disappointed.


中文：
这个游戏有个致命的问题：
才14块钱，卖太便宜了……

更新：
在我通关这个游戏后，我看了一些这个游戏的差评，大多数差评都在说这款游戏很无聊……我不得不承认，从某种角度来说，确实是这样……尽管GRIS有着相当棒的美术设计，但我也不得不承认，有些时候游戏过于无聊，特别是游戏刚开始的时候……在这个游戏中，你能做的只有跑和跳，按K和L，没有攻击，没有Boss战，你永远不会死，因为没血条……好吧，玩这个游戏甚至不需要鼠标……
所以，如果你想放松一下玩会儿游戏，那GRIS挺好的。但是如果你玩游戏是为了追求刺激，那GRIS可能会让你失望。

A beautiful game on so many levels.

However, I felt like I understood most of the symbolism and messages in The Journey while parts of Gris were unclear to me. That isn't a bad thing, though. 150026748.review: Mi primer platino, quedo gratamente satisfecho al completar el 100%, puedo decir con certeza que este juego es la más fina representación del arte, con una historia que no necesita ni una sola palabra para transmitirnos tal belleza y profundidad, Daré mi opinión de los aspectos más importantes que están en el título abarcandolo desde mi perspectiva, para mi la historia símboliza la lucha del ser humano por conseguir un propósito, siendo este representado en el juego como la búsqueda de la voz que perdemos al inicio, el pájaro negro cambiaformas, podríamos decir que son los mayores miedos o obstáculos que nos encuentramos en nuestra vida, la tortuga como las metas o sueños cumplidos, los cuáles son como una luz que en la parte en que sale nos salva y nos da un profundo alivio, la madre de la chica, lógicamente son nuestros padres que nos acompañaron a lo largo de una parte importante de nuestra vida, las estrellas podemos representarlas como las experiencias, estás mismas experiencias nos abren el camino a mejores y más bonitas cosas, siendo el epítome de nuestro esfuerzo, la roquita verde que se vuelve nuestro amigo podemos decir que es nuestra alma de niño que vamos alimentando y al final cuando nos da una estrella, símboliza que esta alma nos da su visto bueno para seguir avanzando a un mejor mañana, por último quería hablar sobre algunas cosas que vi en el juego, el apartado gráfico de verdad que es sublime, me quede sin palabras al ver cada escenario, la música es exquisita y la parte final simplemente es increíble, sin más que decir me despido y espero que el que haya llegado hasta aquí valore el esfuerzo que hice para hacer esta reseña y le recomiendo el juego 10/10.

149968714.review:
Probably one of the most aesthetic pleasing games I've ever got to play, lovely in every sense. 
The story touches you deeply, in a very sensitive and artistic way, through colours and the dress of the main character Gris, the inner child of a girl who is lost in her own world after suffering a traumatic event.
A mirror of a grieving mind and soul, alluding to the five stages of grief in psychology and colour theory, with an even deeper message and hopeful outcome.
Every detail and aspect of this unique masterpiece is so carefully done that it's really one of the best and most beautiful short games ever made to this day.

149966177.review:
I'm conflicted about Gris. 

In one hand, it's a touching story about - I think - a girl going through the five stages of grief, the Kubler-Ross model if you will, after some loss, perhaps a death, though the abstract of the art makes it hard - deliberately and rightfully so - to place in the real world, so ultimately it's up to you to fill the blanks, and feel as you must. 

As a product of art, it excells. Great visual, great narrative, great soundtrack. 

In the other hand, it's a horrible platformer, painfully slow, unchallenging, barely engaging, with exploration elements that exacerbate the already slow pacing. This is the kind of game that doesn't need achievements, and yet there's some "SmaSh all tHe bOXes Hohoi" stuff in there. 

I don't think games need to be fun to succeed - Gris is an example of that - but I would have enjoyed it a lot more if the gameplay part was on par with its artistic merits.

149162107.review:
Me ha parecido... un juego precioso. Me ha transmitido mucho, incluso me ha hecho llorar de emoción.

Eso sí, no es un juego para todo el mundo. No hay game overs, no hay items (aunque sí vas desbloqueando "habilidades", no hay enemigos a los que derrotar... Es solo plataformeo con puzles, y un EXCELENTÍSIMO diseño de niveles, que te lleva por donde quiere, sin que tú seas siquiera consciente de ello, porque no sientes que te cojan de la mano y te guíen de mala manera.

Sé que puede sonar pedante decir esto, pero más que un juego, se siente como una experiencia visual y conceptual muy interesante. La cual, insisto, quizá no sea lo que busques. Pero si has atravesado una depresión, ansiedad, un luto o cualquier fase que te haya hecho sentirte roto/ta o sumido/da en la oscuridad... no dudes en probarlo, Te cautivará.

148324516.review: This is more of a museum, rather than a game--and that isn't a bad thing. I just think that potential buyers should be aware of that. If you watch the trailer and expect a dozen hours of fun and challenging puzzles, that isn't really what this game is about. This game tells a beautiful, heartbreaking story without text or voice acting. Each screen is a breathtaking tapestry, woven into a greater art piece and tied together by one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. critics of the game say it's "boring," and that is a valid take. I think that it just isn't for everyone. $15 is steep, but getting it on a sale is definitely worth it.

148299698.review: What a fun and enjoyable, relaxing experience! This is not a game; this is a masterpiece. It's like you're playing and moving throughout a painting, and the soundtrack merges so well with the art design, which is really beautiful. If I could capture every frame of this game and print it and hang it on my wall, I would do it without any hesitation, and the story of this game is told without saying a single word, breaking every linguistic barrier, so no matter what languages you speak, you would understand the story. The game is not too long; you can complete it with every achievement in about 5 hours. I would recommend you play it without any interruptions, and I would recommend you play it with your headphones on just to enjoy the soundtrack.

147986284.review:
Released in 2018, "Gris" is a visually stunning and emotionally evocative video game developed by Nomada Studio and published by Devolver Digital. This indie gem is a testament to the artistic potential of the gaming medium, offering players a unique and captivating experience that transcends traditional gaming boundaries.

"Gris" immediately captivates players with its breathtaking visuals. The hand-drawn art style, reminiscent of watercolor paintings, creates a world that feels like a living, breathing piece of art. Each frame is a meticulously crafted masterpiece, and the use of color plays a pivotal role in conveying the protagonist's emotional journey. The environments seamlessly transition from desaturated and melancholic tones to vibrant and hopeful hues as the narrative unfolds.

At its core, "Gris" is a deeply emotional and personal journey. The narrative is told without explicit dialogue, relying on visual storytelling and symbolism. The protagonist, a young girl named Gris, navigates a world filled with sorrow and loss, gradually finding her voice and strength. The game skillfully explores themes of grief, resilience, and self-discovery, resonating with players on a profound emotional level.

The music, composed by Berlinist, complements the visual narrative perfectly. The hauntingly beautiful score adapts to the emotional beats of the story, enhancing the player's connection to the experiences of "Gris". The sound design is equally impressive, immersing players in the atmosphere and emotional weight of each moment.

While "Gris" is primarily an atmospheric experience, its platforming elements are well-designed and intuitive. The controls are simple and responsive, allowing players to focus on the emotional journey rather than complex mechanics. As Gris gains new abilities, the puzzles become more intricate, adding a layer of depth without compromising the game's accessibility.

"Gris" is a relatively short experience, but every moment feels purposeful and impactful. The pacing is deliberate, allowing players to absorb the emotional weight of each stage. The game invites contemplation, and its open-ended nature leaves room for personal interpretation, making it a deeply personal and memorable experience for each player.

"Gris" stands as a testament to the artistic potential of video games. It masterfully combines visual artistry, emotional storytelling, and engaging gameplay to create an unforgettable experience. Nomada Studio's debut title is not just a game; it's a work of art that pushes the boundaries of what the medium can achieve. Gris is a must-play for those seeking a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant gaming experience.

147679866.review:
I received this game as a gift from a friend and only finally got around to playing it. 

This game is gorgeous. It tells the tale about grief, losing something important to someone and the five stages one might move through in the process. To be able to do this without a single line of dialogue (singing is not dialogue) is an accomplishment, and I will proudly say that I cried at two different points in this game. 

The visuals paired with the excellent musical score/sound effects elevate this game to where I ranked it. Those two ALONE warrant this game 3 of the stars. It's unfortunate that the keybindings for M+KB are not the best, but it gave me an excuse to break out my PS5 controller and use it for once. I will be replaying the game solely for achievement purposes and getting some screenshots because oh my god this game is pretty. 

If you're looking for a shorter game with an impactful message and some puzzles, this is your game!

I'm 21 years old. This is the first video game I've ever started and finished by myself.

That alone should explain why it took me twelve hours to complete a game that my boyfriend and several Reddit threads claim took them about three to four hours, six tops. But, if I'm being honest, most of my time was spent simply looking and listening. I'm not really trying to review GRIS; I don't think I could. I just want to praise it for being an accessible, beautiful story that has completely and irrevocably transformed my view of video games as a whole.

I was born with Cerebral Palsy, and in my case, it manifests itself as a fine motor disability. Gaming is one of those things I've always written off as too hard for me: my brain moves faster than my hands can, I struggle focusing on perspective, sequences, lefts/rights, etc. I grew up around friends and family who loved to game in their free time, and I would watch in awe as they moved through landscapes with ease, challenged bosses fearlessly, used weapons and combos to defeat their foes. Every once and awhile, I'd ask to try, and no one was ever mean to me about it -- my brother was always patient and tried his best to coach me, but it felt like I genuinely could not make the synapses in my mind connect, no matter how badly I wanted to. Eventually, I wrote off video games entirely, even the "easy" ones -- To this day, if someone suggests firing up Mario Kart at a party, I break into a sweat. I've accidentally thrown myself off of Rainbow Road enough times to earn Yoshi a Purple Heart.

That said, I was not particularly good at GRIS. But, between twelve hours and zero pressure, I was able to build up simple platforming skills that ultimately led me through an emotional, evocative game that I am proud to say I completed -- and I had a damn good time doing it! I never believed people when they told me that, just like the books and films I love, there's a game out there for everyone. GRIS changed my mind. I give it five stars :)

147519851.review:
Expecting more of a platformer like Ori, Gris took me on an atmospheric journey that did not last very long but had me completely captured for the time I played it. It reminded me a lot of Journey on PlayStation 3. You get hardly any information but you just follow the beautiful story and except for some rare occasions where I needed to backtrack my steps, every path I chose seemed to lead me to where I needed to go.
Gris is not a hard game, it is a beautiful guided meditation session, perfectly supported by astonishing and original design as well as a calming and esoteric soundtrack.
Since I have unlocked but 41% of the possible achievements, I think I will return to the game on those occasions where I need a brief escape of reality to immerse myself in the soothing world this Game Studio has created. I recommend this to anyone who just needs a breather...

147403829.review:
I don't even know how to describe the game mechanics, but it's not really important because this isn't a normal game. It's an experience. It's mysterious, atmospheric, emotional, beautiful work of art - and if you've undergone something painful in your life, you'll connect with it on a deep level that's unique to you and it will move you. 

Everywhere you go in this game is visually striking. I daresay it's a masterpiece that's meant to be appreciated, so rushing through it is the worst you can do. It's not for everyone though, specially for those looking for a challenging and fast-paced adventure. 

I can see myself playing this game over and over again when I'm feeling down or am going through something difficult. I feel like it heals the soul in your own time and comforts you in a way that only some games can do. It's definitely in my list of favourite games along with Ori and Spiritfarer.

147391704.review: GRIS es más que un simple videojuego; es una obra de arte en movimiento. El juego sigue a una joven llamada Gris, que navega por su mundo lleno de dolor y esperanza. A medida que avanzas, el viaje de Gris se vuelve cada vez más profundo, reflejando las etapas del dolor a través de un diseño de niveles impresionante y una narrativa emocionalmente resonante. Cada escena parece una pintura en movimiento, con colores vibrantes que reflejan las emociones de Gris. La animación detallada añade una capa adicional de inmersión, haciendo que cada salto y deslizamiento se sienta realista. lo recomiendo

147361464.review:
Gris offers an exceptional blend of platforming and artistry. The level design is a standout feature. For a platformer that is supposed to be a "walking sim," they did a great job; it doesn't feel linear at all.

The heart of Gris lies in its artwork and music. It's simply beautiful. I adore the simple yet subtle use of colors. The environment, all the little creatures, the architecture of the buildings - it's all very charming.

The inclusion of "boss" encounters is a welcome addition; they added rhythm to the game and were nicely staged.

Now for the narrative part (spoilers)

[spoiler] However, the narrative felt rather abstract to me. I went into this game completely blind, and it took me a while to understand what it was about and how everything you go through is related to the 5 stages of grief. I was lacking a clear sense of purpose, and it's not explained enough through visuals alone. I learned from a friend about a secret ending and went to watch it, and man, I wish they included that because it gave so much context, and I would have been able to empathize with her way more during the game rather than after everything. [/spoiler]


Overall, I think it's a great game, and I'm kind of sad it didn't resonate with me more, but I would still recommend it.

147354257.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Gris is, without a doubt, the most beautiful 2D puzzle platformer I've ever played. It may be the most beautiful 2D game of any genre I've ever played
- The visual design of the characters and environments is truly stunning. If you're into soft watercolors, pastel hues, and flowing lines of suggestive of art nouveau, you'll have a great time looking at this one. As a man with a bunch of framed John Dyer Baizley prints adorning his walls, I may be a bit biased
- The music is quite pretty and appropriate for the game's style and themes

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The game's story is more of figurative and emotional than it is literal and plot-driven. Don't go in expecting an overt narrative. If there is a defined story here, it's not supposed to be obvious
- Gris is very chill with a muted range of vibes that run from softly mournful to cautiously hopeful. All that changes with the emotional climax at the end, which feels earned and satisfying

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- This is not a difficult game. By puzzle platforming standards, Gris isn't going to ask much of your brain or reflexes. That's just fine with me. I was happy to turn my brain down for a bit and enjoy the pretty colors
- Due to the simplicity, there isn't much to delve into in terms of gameplay. You run, jump, and sometimes sing to make your way through the game's environment
- It's an easy game to replay due to it's visual appeal and short length. In fact, I played this a few years ago on the Switch. Thanks to a good sale, I was more than happy to pick it up to play again on a bigger screen with better hardware

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- Not that Gris will tax any system very hard. Gris will look gorgeous on any setup. It doesn't take much juice to run well
- The game is 100% style over substance, but it just so happens that the style is so good that you care very little about the lack of gameplay depth

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]7.5/10[/b]. It's not often that I'd recommend a game based solely on its visual appeal, but I'll make an exception here. It's a 3-hour art piece worth exploring

147307465.review: Fun indie game, nice symbolism, great soundtrack

147295752.review:
The concept of an abstract game with a loose/nonexistent narrative representing the five stages of grief using metaphor might sound pretentious as fuck, and normaly it would be, but gris in this regard breaks the mold in an unbelievable way and completely blows it out of the park with breathtaking visuals, incredible music and presentation that couldn't be described as anything less than stellar. 

Every single frame of this game is a painting onto its own (mostly due to the fact that the entire game is handdrawn) and the developers know how to combine music and visuals to create a memorable experience and unforgetable atmosphere.

Even if you don't care for the narrative, the enviroments themselves are lovingly crafted and the acceptance level is something I will be seeing in my dreams for a long time owning to how beautiful it is.

The game is rather short, but arguably that means it doesn't overstay is welcome. With only getting some of the hidden collectibles, my run clocked in at 4 hours or so, if you don't want to buy this game at full price, I'd definitely recommend getting it at a discount, it really is an experieence that I think very few to none people won't find something to enjoy out of.

147249870.review: Gris is a gorgeous game in every aspect. Gameplay is simple but fun, and is overlaid by a phenomenal soundtrack that fits the mood of the game perfectly. The art style is unique and beautiful, and the game takes the general rule of show-don't-tell and does a fantastic job epitomizing just that, kicking you in the feels without a single word. Short game, and I wish it were longer, but in my opinion, it's worth every penny. 10/10

146711612.review:
Surreal and mesmerizing...

    From the second you start your adventure in this melancholy masterpiece, you'll find yourself given just enough to survive your world. It is your choice to persevere as the obstacles become evermore treacherous to resolution.  Just as in life, you'll find yourself taken in by moments of peace and beauty; and in the same breath be stricken by tragedy and despair.  

   There are few experiences in this space that will come close to presenting a dreamlike narrative.  Compelled to move onward in actions alone, your character is trapped in the silence of depression.  This is highlighted further by the breathtaking scores that share an ambiance with your surroundings.

   Will you strike back as grief envelopes you or give in to the darkness of your heart?
   10/10 Will live through this again.

146639542.review:
Por si alguien dudaba de la posibilidad de que los vídeo-juegos sean un arte. GRIS es una historia de un duelo, que se desvela poco a poco, mientras el jugador explora y descubre una serie de preciosos paisajes y escenarios oníricos, acompañados de una música excelente y una dirección de arte excepcional. Es corto y parecerá sencillo a los jugadores más experimentados, pero se descubre como una toma de contacto con el medio perfecta, ofreciendo unas horas relajantes acompañadas de puzzles no demasiado complejos.

Para los coleccionistas: lograr el 100% de logros del juego no supone demasiado esfuerzo. Requiere jugar un par de veces a la historia principal, cosa que facilita el juego de por sí, cuando te lo pasas una primera vez: te permite seleccionar capítulos y check-points más adelante.

Muy recomendado, sobretodo si tenéis ganas de una historia emotiva, un apartado visual exquisito y un reto no demasiado complicado.

Storytelling takes on many forms, and Gris, takes players on a journey through grief, using a blend of the 5 stages of grief  and color psychology to craft a captivating narrative. I appreciate how "Gris" artfully uses colors to depict its protagonist's internal struggle, making it relatable even years after its release.

Gris is a testament to the power of video games as a storytelling medium by offering players a unique opportunity to explore grief and healing in a beautiful way.

Si tuviera que sacarle algo menos bueno, sería que al final se hace algo repetitivo en cuanto a mecánicas y desarrollo. No por las mecánicas en sí, que son muy buenas y te las van presentando poco a poco y eso hace que el juego te sorprenda con cada una de ellas, pero es cierto que el último tramo me ha parecido algo reiterativo.
Sin duda un juego que recomiendo totalmente, aunque entiendo que no es para todo el mundo, ni todo el mundo apreciará su valor más allá de un simple videojuego.

145987738.review:
A quality narrative game about the five stages of grief, and a good example of visual storytelling done right. Not a single word is spoken here, so it’s all rather vague and open to interpretation, but for such a sensitive yet universal topic this was actually a smart choice. You can see how people are filling in the gaps with their own relatable meaning, connecting with the story on a personal level easier than they probably could otherwise.

The gameplay does what it needs to do, i.e. providing some engagement and incentive for exploration while being simple and unobtrusive because it’s not the point here. The visuals are varied and pretty, but also easy on the hardware, which I think is relevant considering the game’s universal appeal. The final area in particular is just beautiful, which is very suitable for something that’s supposed to symbolize acceptance.

Also, an OST from a Spanish band called "Berlinist" with half of the tracks’ names in Japanese? Sign me right up. Personal highlight: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rhmHcnDvx2U]Firmament[/url].

In its elegance, GRIS unveils a world where healing and beauty emerge from the depths of sorrow.

145908025.review:
GRIS is a game that's hard to put into words because it's more like an emotional rollercoaster than your typical video game. From the moment you start playing, you'll be captivated by its beauty and moved by its story.
First things first, the visuals in this game are absolutely stunning. The whole game looks like it was hand-painted with watercolors, and every scene is like a work of art. It's like playing inside a dream, where the colors and landscapes change as you progress. Even if you're not into gaming, you'd be tempted to just watch someone play it for the visuals alone.
The story of GRIS is a powerful one, and what's unique is that it doesn't rely on words to tell it. Instead, it uses the environment, the music, and the actions of the main character, Gris, to convey emotions. It's a story of loss, grief, and healing, and it's beautifully told. You'll feel connected to Gris even though she doesn't say a word, and that's a testament to the game's storytelling prowess.
Gameplay-wise, GRIS is a puzzle-platformer, and it's not too hard to get into. The puzzles are cleverly designed, but it's worth noting that the map design isn't always intuitive. At times, you might find yourself retracing your steps or getting a little lost, but this minor setback doesn't detract significantly from the overall experience. The controls are smooth, making Gris's movements feel graceful and natural.
The music in GRIS deserves a special mention. The soundtrack, composed by Berlinist, is a masterpiece that enhances the emotional impact of the game. It's soothing, haunting, and incredibly atmospheric. Trully phenomenal.
In the end, GRIS is a game that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. It's a visual and emotional masterpiece that's more about the journey than the destination. If you're looking for a game that's not just fun but also deeply moving, GRIS is an absolute must-play a beautiful form of art that leaves a lasting impression on your heart.

[quote=TalePlay][i] Check our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38352719/] Curator Page [/url] for short reviews. If you wish to get more gaming listings, news and reviews check our [url=https://www.youtube.com/@tale_play] Youtube [/url] channel as we release videos there often.[/i][/quote] 
 
[h2]In-depth[/h2] 
[h3] ⚔️ Gameplay & Exploration: [/h3]  
  
GRIS is primarily a walking puzzle platformer that gradually opens up to you as you explore. The world is divided into 5 parts, from which you collect one special ability.

Each newly unlocked ability provides you with more possibilities to traverse and overcome obstacles. Although there are only 5 in number, they are quite interesting and simple to use.

The level design is not complex but beautifully crafted, and each area feels different. Your influence in the world impacts some areas of the world, opening new sections and changing old ones.

Collectibles can be found in the world and sometimes offer a challenge, but overall, they can be obtained with patience and a keen eye.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032092596
 
[h3] 😄 Fun: [/h3]

It's not the most fun game, but neither a pain. I had a lot of intrigue in the world and exploring it was the most interesting thing.
 
[h3] 🏞 Visuals & Presentation: [/h3]  
  
This is the area where the game earns the most points. It's gorgeous, beautifully designed, and highly unique. Levels are pencil-drawn, as are the cinematics.

Its style changes over time as you progress in the game and unlock new areas through colors, breathing life into the world as you do so.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032092432
 
[h3] 🔊 Sound & Voice-Acting: [/h3]  
 
For some reason or another, I really enjoyed the game's soundtrack, the music sung by the main character, and the most critical moments.

The main character, Gris, is not able to talk but makes cute and gentle voices throughout the game, with beautiful melancholic and angelic singing parts at the very end that moved me to the point where I almost shed a tear. It's beautiful, and I really enjoyed listening to this game's music.
  
[h3] 📖 Story & Writing: [/h3]  

GRIS is a game about a journey though grief and it's personal growth that comes with it.
  
GRIS has a very interesting and sad story about a young girl who sings to a statue. The game starts as she loses her voice for unexplained reasons while singing, and in the process, she loses her powers.

She ventures slowly into the world, trying to recover what she lost, and through this journey, you explore both the world and the character. Not much is explained, and it's left for interpretation.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032092032
 
[h3] 🧵 Length & Difficulty: [/h3]  
  
It's fairly a short game and can be completed in a single playthrough if you pay attention or follow guides. It's not difficult except one particular section in Chapter 4.

[h3] ⭕️Verdict: [/h3]  
GRIS is a good, but not perfect, puzzle platformer with an interesting world, art style, and gorgeous music. Although it's not too difficult to understand and play, the game might not be suitable for someone seeking a much more complex and challenging platformer. Nonetheless, I believe it's worth giving this game a shot if you can spare a few hours.

145634992.review: So beautiful and fun.  Love the way they rethought the way things work in the usual platformer mechanics.  Instead of dying and re-spawning -- you never die in this game -- you just fall back to where you were before and then you have to try again.   Also, it is low stress as it never lets you miss anything that you needed.  For example, in other games, I worry that I have missed a path to secret treasure or escape, none of that.  If you need it, you'll just keep hitting walls and you go back and then there's only one way that makes sense.  So now I feel at ease when I hit two ways to go, because the wrong way just circles back, or dead ends, no stress!  Another thing is that the stuff you see in the trailer is only from the first 30 minutes or so.  There are lots of ways you learn to deal with the environment beyond what you see in the promotions -- no spoilers.  The puzzles are fun and mostly easy, but there are times where I have to come back to the game later and let my subconscious sort it out.  :-)  So far I have not needed to seek out any online help.  Many of the puzzles are easy, but there are lot of them, so it it's kind of a speed run of puzzles, which is quite satisfying for me.  Note on keyboard keys: If you play the PC version, go to the keyboard settings and find out what the equivalent to the A and B joystick keys are especially, because sometimes it will tell you to hit A or B, but that is something else on the PC keyboard.

It's a really shame for some truly great bits to have distracting pixelated or choppy elements, especially given they had to sacrifice a live child to the animation studio for each cutscene.

Gris would be embarrassingly self-indulgent if you made it, but because someone else made it about their feelings you only have to fight the much easier beast of second-hand embarrassment.

The artistic skill, a few bits of creative gameplay and most importantly the unflinching grit with which it takes itself entirely and extremely seriously the entire time let me walk away much more invested and even affected than expected back in the first five minutes, when I thought there was no way I could possibly take this game seriously.

144889126.review:
Gris, a short journey through depression and grief.

[h1] Story [/h1]

We play as Gris, a girl whose life has changed dramatically after a sad episode in her life.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1]

It is fairly simple, some metroidvania elements along with some basic gameplay mechanics, nothing stellar nor groundbreaking.

[h1]Graphics [/h1]

It is perhaps the main and most notorious aspect of this game, such delicate and vivid colors adorn everything you see, it's like watching a painting in movement, every detail beautifully crafted with the utmost passion. While the game is quite short with a few stages, all of them offer a different environment that we must colorized bringing them to life once again depicting the emotional state of Gris.

[h1]Sound and Music [/h1]

While the sound in general is decent and does the job by enhancing the environments with atmosphere and ambient, the music is the one that sets the mood and tone of the game along with the graphics, they complement together easily, both intertwined give a feeling of desolation, hope, grief and many other sensations during the story, from subtle piano movements, to clean female vocals, atmospheric yet powerful; to be honest, the music alone is 50% of the game, full of raw emotion.

[h1]The Bad [/h1]

It might be the only negative but it can get a bit repetitive, like a lot, the coming and going sometimes feels like a chore as Gris is quite slow and there is a lot of walking, hopefully the stages are so beautiful that you get distracted by them while fulfilling your tasks.

[h1]Conclusion [/h1]

Gris lacks action and intense moments, but it makes up for the that, it is emotional and quite sad, a journey about grief and overcoming depression, accepting loss and coming to terms with your sorrow. Gris (Spanish for grey) is that, a dull colorless world that we must bring to life once again.

It would be a mistake to get this game expecting an action packed experience, it's not about that. On the other hand, if you want to try something different and unique, Gris is for you.

144730546.review:
[h1] Gris: Embracing Fear and Finding Power Through Art [/h1]

Gris delves into this uncharted territory, using stunning visuals, an evocative soundscape, and metaphoric gameplay. It truly is a beautiful game.

As Gris, a woman who's lost her voice and agency, you confront your inner demons. At first, they're like a tormenting flock of birds, a representation of the fears and pain that hold you back. You begin weak, but with each step, you gain strength, eventually reclaiming your inner power and peace.

The game's art style is mesmerizing. It starts with gentle watercolors and morphs into a vibrant symphony of hues and shapes. The visuals, like shifting layers of a dream, captivate your senses and elevate the experience.

Gameplay evolves in harmony with the art, introducing mechanics that serve as metaphors for your journey. Without spoiling much of the story this game, you learn to stand firm against adversity. 

In Gris, the protagonist uses her dress to transform into a cube, brave strong winds and traverse through various landscapes. It's a lesson in  taking shape to adversities and embracing obstacles, turning them into stepping stones.

As you navigate Gris, its world interacts with you. It's not just about moving through; it's about feeling connected, understood, and motivated to explore solutions. The game weaves details into its fabric that resonate with you and encourage introspection.

My time with Gris was short, but its impact was immense. It's a reminder that sometimes, facing our inner fears and transforming them can lead to astonishing growth. It's a symphony of emotion and a canvas of self-discovery, painting a beautiful picture of resilience and renewal.

[b]A postrock metroidvania[/b]

GRIS is a short indie platformer that relies on visuals, music and sound design to deliver a pleasantly melancholic experience. I guess its main draw is the art style which is unlike anything I've seen in 2D games and grows more intricate and gorgeous as you progress. Although there is plenty of exploration and a sort of antagonist, you're never in danger of being killed or getting lost. There are puzzles that require some platforming and use of new abilities you gain as you move through the story but they mostly require noticing stuff around you and are unlikely to block your progress for long.

I guess your enjoyment of the game depends on whether it catches you in the right mood. Like a 3-hour collection of instrumental rock randomly foisted upon you by YouTube shuffle, you either instantly hate it or grow to love it. For me, it was the latter.

144509147.review:
I really liked GRIS.  I thought it was exactly as long as it needed to be without padding out the game-play.  The art and music direction were sublime.

I was very impressed at how well the levels are designed to funnel you through them effectively, despite never feeling like you've fully explored or found the "edges".  At some point I stopped trying to systematically ensure I'd explored every nook and cranny, and just went whichever way "felt right", and the level design was strong enough to make that not a terribly frustrating experience like it would be in a lot of other games.

Just a really well-made game.  Gorgeous.  I liked it a lot, and platformers aren't really my "thing"!

*** SPOILERS ***

The use of watercolor and the way you restored color to the world as you moved through the stages of grief was gorgeous.  I'm not sure how I felt about the levels being directly correlated to the Kübler-Ross model.  The process of working through trauma lost a little bit of its beauty once I started associating levels to specific "clinical" stages like that.

Puzzle platformer with insane graphics (I don't think I've played any other game with such top tier illustrations). Each world (i.e., color) is supremely well thought out and well illustrated, with great soundtracks that reflect Gris' inner turmoil/happiness/etc. I've seen some reviews online re. the lack of a tutorial, however it is nonetheless very easy to get used to the game mechanics along the way. Definitely not much of a learning curve.

The only con I would write here is that the game does have quite a slow start (esp. the first world where I did get a little bored, albeit awed by the graphics)...so you would need some patience, at least until the no. of mechanics increase + pace picks up by the second world. If you're used to faster-paced platformers like Celeste etc., this game would be far too slow for you. I'd recommend this more to anyone looking for a therapeutic activity to do before bed/after a stressful day at work.

[h1] GRIS: Equilibrio perfecto en jugabilidad, historia, filosofía, arte y música [/h1]

Este juego nos trae una perspectiva de la vida en 2-D, con una banda sonora maravillosa y un arte conceptual único, que supera con creces a lo que se le llama Juegos Triple A.

[h1] Aviso de posible Spoiler [/h1]
[spoiler] El juego trata mucho de los sentimientos tras una perdida, y sus niveles serán las fases de esos sentimientos, llamados, Fases del duelo, los cuales son; Negación, Ira, Negociación, Depresión y Aceptación. Y nuestro mundo se recreará bajo la idea onírica de cada uno de ellos. Si estás leyendo esto y has pasado por ello, sepas que es lo que nos hace humanos, y que jamás dejes de avanzar, pase lo que pase, ya que como en este mismo juego muestra en su mensaje, por mucho que sea el dolor por la pérdida de un ser querido, recuerda en llevarte lo bueno de dicha persona para mantenerla viva en ti. [/spoiler]

[b] Si no has leído ese "Spoiler", no te pierdes nada en sí, solo el comprender el juego, pero insisto que primero lo juegues y ya al acabarlo si lo deseas, vuelvas aquí y leas ese texto. [/b]

Gris tiene un arte brutal en cuanto a mapas, coloridos y música, por lo que recomiendo muchísimo jugarlo con auriculares. Es cierto que la duración del juego es corta, pero es intenso en cuanto a sentimientos y mensaje nos transfiere.
Yo lo he disfrutado muchísimo, he reaccionado a dicho mensaje. Pero también me ha entretenido, lo cual el objetivo de un juego siempre será el entretenimiento, pero si encima en ello, añaden cosas tan importantes en nuestra vida, con esos mensajes que todos vivimos o vemos, es de agradecer. Para mí es un juego que enamora y profundiza en el corazón de quien lo juega.

143813100.review:
This game is definitely unconventional.

Are the graphics impressive? Sure.
Is the soundtrack emotionionally engaging? Without a doubt.
Is the game a remarkable achievement in terms of its content and programming? Certainly.
Is it also, very very boring? Equally true.

So, what's the final verdict on the game?

The traditional rating systems on Steam does not allow for nuanced opinions and, despite my criticisms, I'm not really panning the game.

The main issue lies in the fact that "Gris" leans more towards being an experience rather than a conventional game. However, even as an experience, it leans too heavily on evoking emotions, leaving gameplay and structure behind.

Beneath the surface, there are certainly layers of metaphorical depth, but on the surface level, it often involves solving relatively simple puzzles. These puzzle segments are interspersed with moments where the player is led into semi-interactive "emotional" cutscenes—scenes that give the illusion of control but essentially keep you in a passive role as a viewer.

Additionally, the game's narrative is saturated with pathos to an excessive extent. The soundtrack is a continuous stream of "aaaahs" and "iiiihs," and the themes consistently delve into topics like depression and elation. It's unclear whether this stems from genuine involvement on the developers' part or a hint of cynicism.

In summary: My appreciation for the creative team behind this game is genuine. Yet, keeping my eyes opened while I fought sleep to finish this game was all but easy.

143689884.review:
[ME HIZO PENSAR…]

☐ Sobre el sentido de la vida, el universo, el todo

☑ Sobre la condición humana: sobre el proceso de duelo, si realmente todas las fases son siempre así, si todos las experimentamos igual…

☐ Sobre la sociedad

☐ Sobre las relaciones interpersonales

☑ Sobre la historia o intrigas del juego: ¿quién es Gris? ¿Es real o una representación de algo? ¿Es ella un conjunto de emociones? ¿Es ella una representación de las ganas de superar el duelo? ¿Por qué está en proceso de duelo? ¿Esta larga caída al vacío significa algo dentro del proceso de duelo o es mera coincidencia por diseño de nivel?

☑ En los puzles del juego: no muy complicados, pero a algunos hay que darles un par de vueltas

☑ En nada. Estaba absorto, sumergido en la experiencia: muchas veces te encuentras paseando por el mundo, contemplándolo.

☐ ¿Eh?¿Qué?… Estaba pensando en la lista de la compra


[ME HIZO SENTIR…]

—Sobre el tono general del juego—
☐ Alegría
☑ Tristeza
☐ Asco
☐ Miedo
☐ Rabia

—Sobre la jugabilidad—
☐ Ilusión
☑ Diversión
☐ Indiferencia
☐ Aburrimiento
☐ Decepción

—Sobre mí—
☐ Poderoso
☑ Seguro de mí mismo: no sentía que me fuese a pasar nada
☐ Incómodo
☐ Inseguridad, duda, peligro
☐ Insignificante

—Sobre la progresión de la historia—
☐ Expectación, inquietud: no sabes lo que va a pasar
☑ Esperanza, optimismo: da la sensación de que va a acabar bien, pero no tienes grandes indicios de ello
☐ Pesimismo: pinta mal esto...
☐ El Oráculo de Delfos: se veía a la legua lo que iba a pasar

—Sobre el mundo y estilo—
☑ Síndrome de Stendhal: es hermoso muy por encima de la media
☑ Ternura (oooh! qué liiindo!)
☑ Asombro, contemplación, sorpresa (buah!)
☑ Curiosidad, interés (a ver qué hay por allí…)
☐ Nostalgia
☐ Ansiedad


[ME HIZO REACCIONAR…]

—Momentos de alegría—
☑ Expresión verbal de alborozo (Toomaaa!)
☑ Sonrisa
☐ Pequeña risa (Jejé)
☐ Risa (Jajajaja)
☐ Carcajada (WAJAJAJAJAJA)

—Momentos de tristeza—
☑ Me dio sentimiento en el corasonsito
☐ Nudo en la garganta
☐ Se me humedecieron un poco los ojos
☐ Solté una lagrimilla
☐ NO ESTOY LLORANDO, VALE!? … se me ha metido algo en el ojo

—Momentos de asco—
☐ Cara de asco (fruncir la nariz)
☐ Sonidos de asco (ugh!)
☐ Reflejo faríngeo
☐ Eché la pota

—Momentos de miedo—
☑ Sobresaltos leves
☑ Algún susto ocasional acompañado de improperio
☐ Gritito poco varonil
☐ Salí del juego, lo desinstalé y apagué el pc
☐ Me mudé de casa. La mía quedó maldita

—Momentos de rabia—
☑ Suspiro de condescendencia (...en fin)
☐ Resoplido de desaprobación (hpff!)
☐ Insultos a la pantalla (HIJO DE…)
☐ Golpeé un objeto cercano (*TUF*)

—Momentos eróticos—
☐ Hubo un ligero movimiento ahí abajo
☐ Mojé la ropa interior
☐ Se me puso como el cuello de un culturista

143536993.review:
GRIS is a great narrative-driven game with amazing hand-drawn visuals. It deals with the stages of grief, and without dialogue, the story is also open to interpretation.
Besides the visuals, the animations also look great, coupled with a fitting soundtrack.
Gameplay is mostly a light platformer with some puzzles. It’s nothing special, but it’s just a means to move the narrative forward. The game is also easy and short.
There are some optional collectibles and achievements, although you’ll need a guide to get everything. It extends the game’s length a bit, but besides that, there’s little replay value.
It’s a good recommendation on sale since it’s one of the prettiest games out there. And being short is actually a strength in this case since it’s pretty casual gameplay-wise.

143536157.review: A strange masterpiece. Playing it feels like you step into the canvas of a Klimt painting, mesmerizing sight, unique art style, fun ideas and clever maps and methods througout the entire game. Truly art in every aspect.

143530962.review: The game was short but it was still worth to play. I personally liked the simplistic art, animation, and as the game progresses the world that got crumbled to emptiness became vibrant and lively. The story flows with emotions and metaphors instead of conveying it on a literal text/words so some people might not understand or like it.

143520314.review:
a visually gorgeous game with a powerful representation of grief that becomes clearer as the game progresses.

the gameplay is simplistic, which was perfect for a casual gamer such as myself, and it introduces new mechanics every stage of the game. old mechanics are consistently used throughout each level, which leads to an engaging experience throughout. it also refuses to allow the game to get too dull.

at times there were moments of boredom, mainly because the game relies on the player to find each new segment with little directional aid, and i'd find myself searching for a few minutes fruitlessly before realizing i had missed the entrance several times, but that annoyance was quickly disregarded as the story continued to unfold.

speaking of the story, there is a level of media literacy you'll need to have to unravel it because it isn't outright told to the player. the only thing i knew about this game was that it was vaguely about grief, which made understanding it much easier. i wouldn't recommend going in completely blind, i can imagine being disoriented at some of the major story beats, but dont look up walkthroughs or lets plays. best to just read a few reviews and play.

i bought this game in a bundle on sale, and i'd recommend you'd do the same, as the game is incredibly short, however the animation and sound design are phenomenal so if you're in a financial position to support the amazing team behind GRIS, please do so!

oh, and if you do get the game, make sure to give the little guy plenty of apples!

143461782.review:
Gris is an interesting game because it didn't really affect me at all, I would assume I've just not/not yet gone through the experiences in my life to make me find a connection to this game. I have seen however that it had a massive effect on others so very very subjective experience it seems.
I also found the gameplay to be pretty boring to be honest, I'm by no means a darksouls type player when it comes to enjoying games, I love games from Hollowknight, to Outer Wilds, to Disco Elysium, and that last one isn't famous for great movement lol, but Gris is primarily a platformer as a game so the slow movement and limited complexity felt tedious to me.
On the good though, WOW the visuals and music are fantastic, I did prefer the first level visually but all of the levels have a wonderful sense of architecture to them (again, especially the first which has something of an archaeological appeal as well. The soundtrack never disappointed either, both aspects were fantastic. I would call the story good as well considering that it seems I'm in the minority for it to not have hit me correctly.
All in all, not especially my type of game but I really admire what it was doing and it's fantastically unique so I definitely support it. If you're wary though of course wait for a sale.

One of the best game i ever played, in my opinion this game is more of a travel for your imagination and emotions or at least this is how i went through it; Gris is a journey that tells a story of pain, loss and at the end healing by experiencing the five stages of mourning, in a narrative of emotions without texts or dialogues. 143300086.review:
That giddy feeling that traverses your body from head to toe when you discover something that resonates with the very fibers of your soul is heightened when it is placed before you by some Invisible Force. Was it a mere coincidence a (City and) Colour track was playing in the background or was it Meant to Be? 

This is an introspective journey of loss and grief. An artistic platform-adventure that has you progress through the five stages of grief. Every stage is full of symbolism, starting in a world devoid of color. Slowly, the color returns as you collect mementos or memories hidden in her magical inner world. 

In a word, simply beautiful. A captivating reminder about the magic of video games.

An Invisible Force or a well-tuned algorithm? The answer matters not. My heart thanks you.

143288948.review:
I played the game for a total of 110 minutes with a friend who was appreciative of the game, and when I alt-tabbed at the 110 minutes mark I felt that if I wasn't with a friend I would've refunded it immediately if not long before, so I did.

I don't understand why people are so blown away by the art direction and the music to the point that they are willing to pretend the story follows any sort meaningful character or story. The development team cast their line very solidly at the art department that, yes every screenshot of the game does look downright wallpaper material that people don't consider what they are even doing within the game.

I doubt even the most steadfast fan would defend the game on it's rights as a platformer or a puzzle game. There was only a single puzzle during the crystal cave area that stumped me and I feel it was an extension of how internally disinterested I had become at the game that I wasn't willing to pay attention to it. In addition every single power you got in the game was entirely unhepful towards platforming that I think just replacing the segments where you need to use them with a context sensitive autoplay option would have improved my experience as having access to them at all times made me try for any interaction with the world's environment to get any sort of enjoyment out of the platforming (there wasn't any).

In conclusion, don't engage with this game, utter chore.

143287201.review:
Gris is a brief and gentle puzzle platformer with a distinctive art style and notable soundtrack. The gameplay is somewhat simple but it doesn't really need to be anything else for the purpose of the game's story and vibe. The art has shading somewhat reminiscent of Supergiant games while also reminding me somewhat of the work of Yoshitaka Amano. I would say that if the art in the previews appeals to you, I would check out the game - its only around 3-6 hours long and has a cohesive metaphorical narrative. 

In terms of the narrative, it is quite simple but gets its point across effectively. The sections with [spoiler] the bird and the eel [/spoiler] felt to me to be a little bit too dramatic for the tone of the game, especially in conjunction with the music. I can see these sections being highlights for some people though so I would say this comes down to personal preference. The same can be said about the music in general - sometimes it is very effective, especially in the more ambient sections. The multilayered countermelody that is produced when [spoiler] you unlock the singing ability [/spoiler] is a particularly good example of this. However, I feel that sometimes the music does a bit too much of the thinking for the player and takes away from the games stellar sound design. Some of my favourite moments of the game were when I was just left to explore with the ambient sound of the game's world as the backdrop. If you want a game where you can quietly sink into a melancholy yet soothing vibe, then I would recommend Gris.

Genres: [i] platformer, puzzle, iyashikei [/i]
Difficulty: [i] 2/10 - Very easy [/i]
Rating: [i] 7/10 - Great! [/i]

143272389.review:
I went into this game with very little expectations, other than it looked—judging from the trailer—like a very pretty puzzle platformer. What I got, was nothing sort of a masterpiece.

The creative minds at Nomada Studio set out to develop a game unlike anything I had ever seen before. It’s a puzzle platformer without any combat or fail states. There’s no text or exposition, but there’s a story, and while it may not be immediately obvious, it will still somehow manage to convey to you the intense grief and pain the main character feels. But what will definitely stand out to the most, is the exceptional visual design and soundtrack.

Let’s begin with gameplay.

Like I said twice already, Gris is a puzzle platformer. The game starts very slowly. For the first few minutes I was wondering where everything shown in the trailer went. It felt as though I was just walking around in a barren wasteland.

That is part of the beauty of this game. As you progress, you collect lights that resemble stars (which later also form constellations that open up new paths). These lights unlock new abilities for Gris, the main character the game is entitled after.

As soon as you unlock the very first ability, you immediately begin to see that the true depth of this game. It’s not that the puzzles are somehow unique, but they’re entertaining. Very entertaining. I have to say this because you might feel—like I did—doubtful during the first few minutes. Be patient. There are some very smart and fun puzzles in this game, and they get progressively better. In fact, the last level felt like a culmination of it all and was just a lot of fun to play through.

None of the puzzles will ever seriously challenge you. That’s not what Gris is about—and I appreciate that. I enjoyed playing a game for the sensorial experience, and the excitement of figuring out how to solve puzzles that make me think for a minute, but never frustrate me.

Your first playthrough is going to be linear, and once you finish the game for the first time, you’ll be able to revisit past levels. Don’t worry about leaving anything behind. The game will make it clear where you’re supposed to go. I’m a pretty unintelligent person, and I never had to pull up a guide or anything. This game was very accessible.

I also just have to say that it’s refreshing to play a puzzle platformer that doesn’t include any combat or fail state. I never felt anxious. That’s good. Sometimes anxiety makes games more immersive. Gris managed to do it without the anxiety.

The highlight of this game though has to be the visual design.

It’s unlike anything I’ve ever seen. I can’t even think of anything to compare it to. They took four really basic environments (what I’d call, a red sand desert, a lush forest, underwater caves, and a “space garden made of light”), but put an otherworldly aquarelle spin on them, that just completely blew my mind. Honestly. So much of the game could be a painting on a canvas. I showed the trailer to my wife, and even she was blown away. I know that, from now on, every time someone tells me that games aren’t art, I’ll be thinking about Gris. I mean, five out of the eight awards Gris won, were somewhere in the category of visual art. That should tell you something about how good the art style in Gris is (and how great the game is in general, considering all the nominations).

And along with a great visual design, came an excellent score.

There is not a single moment in this game where I felt that the music was out of place. Quite to the contrary. It always knew exactly what emotion I was supposed to feel at any given moment. The music is equally parts epic, reflective, emotional, personal, and fittingly atmospheric. It is so good, all of it, that I’m actually listening to the official soundtrack as I type this out. This is big praise coming from me. I couldn’t write a single word on a notepad while listening to music if my life depended on it. But the music in Gris is just… it’s something else. It’ll be listening to it for years to come.

My first playthrough took me close to four hours. There’s quite a few collectibles I missed, so maybe there’s an additional two or three in there. All-in-all, you’re getting your money’s worth for $15 on Steam, and I got it on discount for five times less than that, if I remember correctly, so I got a really sweet deal. And you should too.

Gris is an experience. Its simple and fun gameplay never gets in the way of that experience. It’s one of those games you play to see and hear something different and memorable. If someone asked to visualize a painting of a game, Gris would more of less be what would come to my mind.

I give Gris two thumbs up. I highly recommend it.

I've only played this game a bit, but I can just tell this storytelling is not going to work for me. The first main issue is that I can't connect to the character because there's nothing tangible to latch onto. It feels like I am just being bombarded with art and music that is loosely connected to some events I'm not privy to. 

However, I don't think being abstract is a flaw on it's own. It just makes the storytelling more challenging since it is harder to build a connection when you don't have concrete stuff to latch onto. The real issue is that the quality of the storytelling here is just lacking. For example, the pacing is borked from the start. One of the first things that happens is that the game plays over the top dramatic music as she is she is sliding down a hill. This is a thing that would totally work if it happens after I'd actually gone through anything with this character. I've only been playing a few minutes at this point, so how am I supposed to be affected by this? I wish even a tenth of the effort that went into the art and music had gone into building a strong narrative.

De estos juegos cortos que molan mucho por su dirección artística y que te dan un respiro agradable de tanta acción y derrotar monstruos, enfrentarte a alienígenas o derrotar a dioses. Personalmente la experiencia ofrecida por GRIS me ha gustado mucho y me ha recordado a aquella vez que jugué Journey por primera vez, al ser bastante parecidos.

Y además viene de un estudio español, por lo que bonus points por ese lado :)

[h2]Lo bueno[/h2]
[list][*] Dirección artística muy buena, es como jugar sobre un lienzo muy bien pintado
[*] La banda sonora es por lo general relajada, pero en los momentos de tensión gana una fuerza increíble
[*] Plataformeo lo suficientemente entretenido para mantenerte agarrado a la pantalla
[*] Cortito y directo a lo que importa
[*] Coleccionables y secretos escondidos a lo largo de los distintos mapas del juego para los más 'completionistas'
[/list]

[h2]Lo malo[/h2]
[list][*] Aunque es cierto que hay muchos coleccionables y secretos, no me vi especialmente motivado a conseguirlos
[*] Bastante sencillo y más allá de una experiencia bonita le falta algo para la gente a la que le gusta un reto
[/list]

Para mi no es que haya sido un descubrimiento frente a otros juegos que he jugado previamente, pero si que lo he disfrutado y me ha entregado el mensaje que se quería transmitir, el cuál es bonito y profundo, por lo que merece la pena.

142824641.review:
[h1] [b] An Artistic Masterpiece of Emotion!! [/b] [/h1]

GRIS is an awe inspiring gem that transcends the boundaries of a traditional video game and embraces the realm of interactive art. From the moment you enter its surreal world, you'll be captivated by its striking visual design and heart-wrenching narrative.

The game's artistic prowess is nothing short of breathtaking. Every frame feels meticulously crafted with hand-drawn animations that effortlessly flow into each other, creating a mesmerizing visual symphony. The color palette evolves with the story, conveying the protagonist's emotional journey, from desolate greys to vibrant hues that breathe life into the surroundings.

Accompanied by an ethereal soundtrack that tugs at your heartstrings, GRIS invites you to explore a universe of emotional depth. There's no dialogue or text to guide you; instead, the game relies on evocative imagery and symbolic storytelling to convey the protagonist's tale of grief and self-discovery.

Throughout the journey, you'll solve puzzles that serve as metaphors for overcoming personal obstacles, each one deepening the bond between the player and the protagonist. This seamless blend of gameplay and emotional storytelling sets gris apart from other experiences.

Despite its short duration, gris manages to leave an indelible mark on players. Its poignant narrative, breathtaking art, and soul stirring soundtrack merge into a experience that stays with you long after the final credits roll.

GRIS is not just a game. it's a moving piece of art that resonates with your emotions and offers a unique and unforgettable journey. Whether you're an avid gamer or an admirer of exquisite art, GRIS is an essential experience that shouldn't be missed.

142624201.review:
Tenía pensado jugar GRIS desde el momento en que salió a la venta. Sin embargo colgué con otros juegos, y la vida misma, y pude jugarlo recién, habiendo olvidado todos los trailers y reseñas que me la habían recomendado. Y debo decir que me llevé una enorme sorpresa.

Es una breve, pero justa y necesaria, aventura gráfica de plataformas 2D que en parte recuerda a Journey, en donde empezas sin saber nada y solo tenes que adentrarte en unos apabullantes paisajes, que en este caso, son creados por la sensible imaginación de una chica trastornada por una pérdida de un ser querido.

A nivel jugable, solo tenes que resolver algunos sencillos puzzles mientras vas atravesando un proceso de superación a nivel emocional. Te lo podes pasar en una tarde, asique recomiendo jugarlo de corrido para no desentonar de la experiencia.

Su banda sonora es tan espectacular (a la par de Ori and the Blind Forest/Will of the Wisp y Hollow Knight) que recomiendo jugarlo con auriculares para deleitar tus oídos en la inmersiva aventura.

Tanto imagen, sonido y jugabilidad se va acomplejando a medida que avanzas así como también su hermoso arte que es simplemente magnífico.

No necesitas saber más nada, todo se cuenta a través de los sentidos. El resto es un proceso, una delicada experiencia perfectamente acompañada por unas animaciones de dibujos simplemente espectaculares!

Que más se puede decir ante semejante orquesta visual y sonora, donde las emociones danzan al compás de ese proceso tan personal y especial todos tenemos o tendremos alguna vez?

Todos tus sentidos van a agradecer haberse expuestos ante esta imperdible obra de arte!

Bueno, después de haberlo jugado de salida pirata por fin he vuelto a rejugarlo y a recordar lo buen juego que es. Plataformas precioso que no deja indiferente a nadie, y que personalmente tiene una carga emocional muy importante.

Lo amé más si cabe cuando conocí a una persona, ya que es su juego preferido. Y jugarlo hoy, cuando ya no está en mi vida, en esta fecha tan especial para ella, hace que sea aun más especial. Ha sido como jugar dos juegos diferentes. Hace años me marcó, y ahora he vuelto a él en otro momento complicado y lo ha vuelto a hacer.

No ha sido, emocionalmente hablando, nada fácil volverlo a jugar, con toda la relevancia que ha ganado ya en mi vida por culpa (o gracias) a ella. Pero tenía que volver. No es el momento en el que había deseado volver, pero creo que es justo cuando lo necesitaba. Ha sido otro paso más en todo esto que llevo viviendo ya casi un año. 142265585.review:
A really fun game that makes you think.

This game is one of the only games I leave the music on as it doesn't get annoying and sets the setting.
The soundtrack is really well made and I plan to buy the DLC.

Gris discusses the topic of grief and its stages of it. It does this so abstractly that if you don't know, you can still enjoy the game. It delivers the stages of grief in absolutely stunning scenes.

The artwork in the game is aesthetically pleasing and gives clear indications of each chapter and level you are on. I spent some time looking in the gallery and it's really interesting to see how the game progressed through development.

The gameplay is seamless and provides a challenge. Each level has an assortment of puzzles that we, the player, must solve to move on. Each new chapter provides a new skill and more colour in the environment. The puzzles themselves were really fun to solve and some of them are really challenging if you don't see certain clues in the environment.

But with all games comes some issues. My main problem with the game is sometimes you jump onto a platform only to fall straight through it but the next time you attempt the same action it works. Another issues that I had was that you cannot skip cut-scenes when playing through for achievements when you have finished the game. Some cut scenes are playable but the game does not indicate to you that they are.

Overall, Gris is a beautiful and fun game to play. I highly recommend it to my friends.

THE MUSIC IS A W

142235873.review:
Yes, the art is quirky and wondrous. It works pretty well in inducing a dull feeling of bleakness. The puzzles are clever, at a few occasions a bit frustrating but overall they are pretty creative and clever. So far so good, which begs the question why I don't suggest you play this game. 
Well, clever puzzles and great art only ever amount to anything if they contribute to a memorable story or an interesting experience, otherwise you have a disjointed game with really beautiful limbs scattered around much like the big stone statue in Gris. I think what has ruined this game is insisting on an extreme level of abstractness to the point that renders the game devoid of the potential to elicit sympathy and a touching emotional connection. Even the synopsis reflects this gaping vagueness as the game is described as the story of a young woman who has had a painful experience. What that painful experience was is left to the player's imagination which by the end of the game is sufficiently numbed by the bleakness of the world. 
It is painful to have to say these things about a game that was clearly made with love and care but it is what it is and despite my best efforts to feel something at the end as the cutscene rolled out and depicted a very predictable eventuality, the only emotions I had were pity for the game as it was trying to make me cry or something watching the final cutscene as the supposedly epic music played while the statue came together, and also a feeling of deep regret for the time I spent playing it. 
What makes so many people adore it, I simply don't know. The scarcity of games with original ideas perhaps. I hail the developers for all the many things they got right in this game and walk away from Gris with nothing but a futile wish that they would have also given those pretty limbs a spine, that beautiful, statue a soul.

142180367.review: The art style of this game is simply incredible - gorgeous environments, fantastic use of color and shape, diverse environments that nonetheless feel like they're still part of the same world...everything about GRIS's visuals is gorgeous, an absolute feast for the eyes. It's disappointing for me, then, that I felt like I didn't connect with the metaphors of grief running throughout the narrative. Perhaps it's because I personally don't think I've experienced anything in my life that would cause me to recognize the game's imagery, or perhaps the game is simply abstract enough that it doesn't present these themes very clearly. Beyond that, the gameplay is fine, clearly a secondary consideration to the narrative and artwork - good, basic puzzle platforming that can occasionally be frustrating or feel unclear. I think that this game can connect with a lot of people, so it makes me a little frustrated that it didn't connect with me, but I firmly believe it's worth experiencing nonetheless.

This is a masterpiece, an absolute must-play that pushes video games forward as a powerful platform for storytelling and expression. Gris is a form of art that can be played. As a player it's easy to see the sheer amount of detail and care that was put into every aspect of it, but at the same time it all disappears, to a point where music, art, interaction and story all blur into each other. Same as reading a really good book, everything just fades away and only the experience of the magical, of the connection and the emotion remains.

Gris is a work of love, and to make it even more touching (or because of it) it deals with loss and grief, as human an experience as they come. Just go play it already!

Gracias a su bello apartado artístico y a la sensibilidad que prometía, me atreví a darle una oportunidad a GRIS (además de que sabiendo de que es un estudio español incita a querer apoyar) y la verdad es que no he acabado en absoluto decepcionada.

GRIS es un título que sin necesidad de narración alguna, tan solo con los colores, los sonidos y los escenarios nos relata los sentimientos de la protagonista y la evolución de estos ante un momento duro de su vida. Es un indie de plataformas ingenioso pero no excesivamente complejo que ayuda a sumergirse en la atrapante atmósfera sin frustraciones (al menos sin buscar el 100%).

En cuanto a su BSO encaja perfectamente con la aventura que vivimos y quiero alabar en especial la voz de la protagonista, por lo que prácticamente es obligatorio jugarlo con cascos.

En resumidas cuentas, GRIS es un indie muy recomendable en especial si está de oferta, no dudes en darle una oportunidad si te llama la atención y buscas un título corto, emotivo, relajante y atmosférico.

I went into playing this game with little knowledge besides having a great soundtrack, and I think everyone should do the same. In that spirit, I'm going to avoid any major details about the game.
I almost never like platform games because they can be too complicated and I end up spending way too long getting frustrated at navigating a complex environment and solving difficult puzzles. I hate reviewing items like this.  For starters, I did not like it.  The problem is that this was good, & extremely beautiful.  It's that kind of conflict that I have where I can't recommend it, but I still think it's wonderful.

First, calling this a game is a great disservice.  As the player, I feel cheated by the lack of any story.  I kept going back to the game description, and descriptions online, and read a summary of a story.  Yet I found it nowhere.  If I ignore the lack of story, and focus on the puzzle platforming, it is nicely done.

The beauty of this software, both in the audio and visual department lead me back to the feeling that this is a piece of art.  Like any good art, it can be decisive.  I just don't get it.

By the time the game was almost done, I REALLY wanted to be done with it.  That probably became a nagging complaint at about the 3 hour mark, but I did finish things at just under 3.5 hours (minus the ending credits).

I can't complain about this game at a sale price, but it was not an item for me.  I would highly suggest watching some online game play before buying this game, as I do think that it deserves an audience, even if it's not me.

141302294.review:
[h1](9/10) UNA EMOCIONANTE OBRA MAESTRA VISUAL, Y MARAVILLA AUDITIVA.[/h1]
[b]GRIS, un juego que va más allá de los estándares... centrándose en su apartado visual basado en acuarelas, y el sonoro, del que destaca su gran OST. 
Rescato momentos de clímax inolvidables y únicos.
[/b]

[hr][/hr]


Gameplay simple de mecánicas sencillas, que es usado como un motor de avance para la historia nada más. Cumple, ya que el juego no exige mecánicas adicionales ni dificultad más elevada.

Buenos puzzles, algunos desafiantes, y otros sencillos. Una experiencia bien balanceada.

La historia es muy emotiva, llena de metáforas, que no solo se cuenta a través de acciones de los personajes, sino también a través de su hermoso universo visual y auditivo. Las pistas que componen su soundtrack acompañan los sentimientos a la perfeccion.

El juego se divide en múltiples colores que representan un apartado de la personalidad de la protagonista. Esto me pareció una decisión de diseño magistral, que da un momento para cada cosa que se quiere contar. No solo eso, sino que te da una verdadera sensación de avance y aventura, que al final termina conectando TODO.

Es una pequeña aventura de duración justa, que no se estira y da todo lo que puede de sí. Esto termina en una experiencia sólida y concisa.

SOUNDTRACK 10
APARTADO VISUAL 10
HISTORIA 8
GAMEPLAY 7

141290749.review:
[i]The most terrifying thing is to accept oneself completely.[/i] - Carl G. Jung

That's the notion I got from this masterfully crafted experience. 

I'll keep it concise, to avoid spoilers. I expected GRIS to be your average puzzle platformer. I'm glad, that I've been proven wrong. Each colour complements the 5 stages of grief accordingly. I've never seen a video game put it so subtly yet effectively into motion for the viewer to experience. From visual representation to music background. I can't say for sure how your experience will be, but it certainly will vary from person to person. It's unique and memorably beautiful in any way. 

However, I only recommend you to play this, if you're in the right mindset. It's quite the melancholic endeavor with a bittersweet undertone.

141277454.review:
[h1]This game is a masterpiece.[/h1]

[i]"Worth the full price, during a sale there is no excuse!"[/i]

The amount of creativity that went in to the visuals, musical score, storytelling, level design and game mechanics is just unbelievable. I would recommend this game to just about everyone, especially those who consider games to be a form of art.

My first playthrough was a few years ago. In the beginning I found it hard to get the vibe of the game, but after letting it rest and starting from the beginning, I got swept away by it and probably completed the whole thing in one 6-hour sitting. At the time of writing I just finished it a second time, going for the achievements I missed.

Thank you Nomada Studio and everyone involved in making this. You made a thing of beauty!

Expect an interactive exploration of a giant piece of artwork, and be pleasantly surprised by the Zelda-like and genuinely innovative puzzle elements and smooth player handling.

141036194.review:
Gris is a beautiful game that is stunning in the overall message of the game, the soundtrack, and the games artwork.
It is not a hard game. There might be a couple of parts that you get stuck on for a second, but it is fairly easy.
The games length is very short as well. I completed it in 3 and a half hours so it is a nice short game. I had no idea what this game was about going into it, but as soon as I started it, it captivated my curiosity and my interest. I could not stop playing it until I finished, and wish that there was more. The creativity in the different chapters is incredible and impressive in different aspects.
The emotion that you feel as you uncover more about the story, what happened, and the interpretation for it is amazing to say the least and expresses going through grief in a very creative way. It isn't depressing. There are definitely some moments that make you tense up, but most of the game is a calming experience.

an absolute masterpiece.
(bought on steam to support, played on a different platform thus low hours)

one of the most emotional games I've ever played and it achieves this without the need for any form of text or dialogue.
the art-style is (as you can see from the screen shots) spellbinding and refined, there isn't a single moment in this game you couldn't screen cap and make into a print. 

the real gem in the crown is the TOTALLY MIND BLOWING soundtrack, which I listen to several times a week. Absolutely one of the best pieces of music written in the past 10 or so years. Berlinist sculpts this perfect tension and release, which delivers an underlying sense of anguish punctuated with hope. I feel you can experience the emotional journey of this game without even playing it (although of course you should) just because the soundtrack is so exceptional and worthy of praise in it's own right.

I'd say this is a strong contender for a "perfect" game. It truly bridges game and art.

Gris elevates the main aspects of the game to such a sublime level that it is difficult to find parallels, and if so, they will be totally different identities.
The potential is demonstrated right away in the opening cutscene, there we see not only how beautiful it will be visually (and believe me, the closer to the end, the more beautiful it gets) or the mastery and sensitivity of the soundtrack that NEVER falls in quality. The narrative is, for me, the part of this set that makes everything even more beautiful. Deep questions handled with care in an interesting and allegorical world that knows how to balance curiosity, simple mechanics and the evolution of the narrative very well, there are few games that have already achieved such quality in mental health issues with so much tact and sensitivity.
All of this is closed with a simply chilling ending. Gris has no error, nothing to change. A jewel in the world of video games.
