140588759.review:
A colorful platformer from the minds of Spanish company Nomada Studio, Gris tells the haunting story of a young girl coming to terms with losing her mother. To do this, she’s tasked with collecting light across several biomes. Which is where the theme of color comes in. Gris uses bold colors to both represent emotions and make astonishing landscapes to traverse. From blue-accented underwater caves to windy red sand deserts, each section uses striking mono or dual tones that make exploring the game a veritable treat, all underlit by a serene, contemplative soundtrack that I just had to download after finishing the game. As you progress you’ll become increasingly antagonized by black ink creatures, who serve as the sole foes of Gris, requiring puzzle-solving to evade or outright defeat them. I’m personally a fan of them. They provide brief bouts of tension to show the young girl’s inner turmoil in addition to pumping in a dose of urgency to your actions.

Whether I was escorting a newly-acquainted buddy across lush forests or running for my life through Greek architecture from giant crows, my interest never dipped, nor did confusion or frustration rear their heads. It might not be obvious at first the true goal of the game, but as you near the ending and the young girl regains her voice and thus her ability to sing, it becomes abundantly clear what she wishes for and finally gains. Peace with her mother’s passing. It’s a somber feeling to be certain, yet as the credits rolled and she ascended the clouds, it wasn’t despair I was feeling. It was contentment. The obvious contentment from playing an A+ game, but also a closure for the main character that couldn’t help but leave me hopeful. While the story leaves little room for a sequel, you better bet I wouldn’t hesitate to hop on that quicker than a fly on honey.

140235645.review:
It was impossible to hold back tears at the end. This game is utterly beautiful. But it also has good gameplay! It's pretty straightforward but there are quite a few times when you need to think about your movements. It's very rewarding. 

The paths to progress are easy to follow and you can't really get lost, even though the areas are big. Optional collectibles (mementos) can sometimes be easy to miss, but if you pay attention to your surroundings you'll be able to get most of them without a guide. And you can always go back to areas once you've completed the game, so nothing is really "missable" for completion. I feel like the developers tried to be as fair as possible to their players. 

There were truly some gorgeous moments when the visuals and music came together during certain parts. The build up of the art and colours throughout was really wonderful too.

As soon as I finished the story, I went back for another playthrough to find all the missing mementos from start to finish. I admit that the first time I kinda rushed towards the end because I was so curious about the story. After that, I was more careful with exploration and absorbing the environment, with all the details and changes that happen. 

It was just as enjoyable the second time around, which I think is a testament to the quality of the game and its design.
I think whether you just want to finish the story or go for 100%, you will appreciate the experience if the visuals capture your attention.

140231805.review:
Well, this is a little frustrating. Obviously the game looks absolutely stunning and has a really great soundtrack. As a piece of art, it's wonderful, however at a game it fails in more ways than one.

First of all, this should (even tho it is verified) not be played on the steam deck (like I did). The character is increadibly small most of the time, making it hard to to see where you are or where you are going.

These next parts are not related to the deck however. The game communicates foreground/background and interactable things very poorly from time to time, which breaks your journey and let's you run around a lot, only for you to realize you were in the correct spot before. This goes hand in hand with the fact that most of this game is simply moving. Like a walking simulator, walking into some direction.
Most of the times, the parkour isn't difficult at all, but here and there some platforms etc. are really really badly spaced, forcing you to either jump from the very last pixel to barely make it or sometimes you will overshoot. That combined with the long walking means if you fall, you will have to go back quiet a bit before you can try again, which makes parkour really infuriating some times.

140141736.review:
I started playing this game with no spoilers and nothing particular in mind. I had no idea what was to come or anything - only that it would be a platformer game of sorts with beautiful art, I guess. I played for about 40 minutes or so. I understood nothing; I was lost and a little bit frustrated. The only actions the game allowed me to do were walk and jump - and walking was made difficult by a particularly infuriating storm. I stopped and complained a little bit about the game.

I decided to start over and see if I missed something - and boy, did I miss. I had taken the wrong turn at the beginning of the game. I went backwards and saw a beautifully laid-down statue. The girl kneeled, seemingly saddened. I didn't click anything - I didn't want to rush that moment. What was that about? I admired the beauty of such strange melancholy - then she stood up, and an achievement popped up. It was the turning point of all my previous emotions towards the game. Everything I was experiencing while playing it made sense. If you have ever been in the girl's shoes or looked through her eyes, you'll immediately know. You'll know the name and the feeling for the next four achievements.

Everything in the game is beautifully put together. All five chapters, the monsters (or demons), all the colors, and all the pain of existence while the beauty of what was still lingers inside of you.

I do hope you play this game. I hope you feel embraced by it and that it helps you process what you are going through.

May the empty void of colorlessness never make you stop.
May the furious destruction of red make you break only what is bad.
May the foolish dealings of green never make you a fool.
May the tear-dropping of blue fulfill the clean waters of your mind.
May the good memories of yellow times linger forever in your heart.

Keep going for those who kept going for you.

139790466.review:
Title: The Exciting Journey of Expressive Arts: A Review of GRIS

INTRODUCTION:
GRIS is an incredible and emotionally charged indie game that takes players on a uniquely personal journey. Created by Nomada Studios, this masterpiece blends craftsmanship with exquisite visuals, captivating audio and allegorical storytelling to create a moving experience on a deeply personal level GRIS stands for a testament to the power of video games as an art form, pushing the boundaries of history and the appeal for players in a deep exploration of grief, loss and healing.

VISUALS:
One of the most interesting aspects of GRIS is its intricate design. The handcrafted art style brings each frame to life with delicate and meticulous detail. The game’s world is an expertly crafted canvas, evolving and changing as players progress through the story. Each stage is incredibly colorful and bright, conveying emotions ranging from desolation to hope. The graphics alone are enough to draw players in and immerse them in a world that feels familiar and ethereal.

AUDIO:
The audio system of GRIS plays an important role in enhancing the emotional impact of the game. The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack composed by Berlinist pairs well with the gameplay and visuals, enhancing the experience. Musical composition and ambient sound create a sense of atmosphere and evoke emotions, adding depth and resonance to the story GRIS' audio elements are central to its appeal, and effectively convey underlying themes and connects players to the protagonist’s journey.

NARRATIVES & THEMES:
GRIS is an abstract metaphorical story about a young woman named Gris, navigating a world shaped by her grief and loss. While intentionally open to interpretation, the piece explores themes of adversity, personal growth, and the transformative power of resilience. The lack of dialogue encourages players to reflect on their experiences and imbues the game with a universality that allows everyone to make their own sense of the story into a deeply emotional and self-inviting journey call for reflection and self-reflection.

GAMEPLAY:
In terms of gameplay mechanics, GRIS is a relatively straightforward platformer with puzzles and light exploration elements. The interface is simple and intuitive, allowing players to focus on the experience rather than complex mechanics. While the puzzles aren’t overly complex though, they are meaningful metaphors and symbolic images of the protagonist’s emotional state. While some players may prefer more complex gaming mechanics, it’s worth noting that GRIS prioritizes overall experience over gameplay depth.

CONCLUSION:
GRIS is an interactive masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and emotional engagement in video games. Its stunning graphics, compelling audio and illustrative story combine to create a transcendent medium experience. While its gameplay mechanics may not offer incredible innovation, the game’s true power lies in its ability to resonate on a deeply personal level, giving players a cathartic and poignant journey of grief, healing and self-discovery that GRIS stands for a testament to the power of video games as an art form and indeed it is It is a must play for anyone looking for a transformative and emotionally rich experience.

IF I COULD EXPLAIN HOW THIS GAME MADE ME FEEL I WOULD BE HERE FOR MORE THAN THE PLAY TIME. I GOT TO THE END OF THE GAME AND I WAS LEFT SPEECHLESS WITH TEARS ROLLING DOWN MY FACE, I FELT SOMETHING THAT I HAVEN'T FELT IN SO LONG. I felt heard.

139419999.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1] 

Gris is an atmospheric platformer game with puzzle elements and special "Powers" you unlock as you play. Finding this game was once again a matter dumb luck for me, and I'm sure glad to be lucky! I will try to divide this review into three parts: Art, Gameplay, and Music.


[h1] The Art [/h1]

The first thing i noticed about Gris was the art. Everything is gorgeous, the backgrounds, the atmosphere, the characters; it stood out more than anything else. The use of colour in Gris is immeasurably beautiful in a way i've never seen before. Gris' (the character) design is great in so many ways; it is so simple yet so eye catching, and the way they use her dress for her powers is really clever and i enjoyed unlocking and using every single one! The animation is just as great. [b] Conrad Roset [/b] is the lead artist for Gris. His influence and style are clearly seen throughout, and it is magnificent. If you like his work, this game is for you!


[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]

Gris' gameplay as a platformer is pretty solid. There isn't much to say about it other than it's done well (but this is coming from someone who's never played platformers). The powers are well implemented and they never feel useless; i appreciate that even in the later stages they still make opportunities for Gris to use her less recent abilities. None of the powers are super strong or 'OP'. They all have their own uses and will come in handy no matter where you are (note this game does not have combat). The level design is good. I didn't find myself feeling stuck or lost, and i didn't do anything i wasn't intended to. Everything was done the right way.


[h1] The Music [/h1]

The music of Gris is just as special as the art, and the two work perfectly together. Every single track is good (even the unused works!), and i cannot find the words to express just how stunning it is. All i can do is thank [b] Bernalist [/b] for making it, and recommend that [b] YOU [/b] buy the soundtrack.


[h1] Extras, The Story, and me blabbering [/h1]

I only played Gris when i felt like it, which for me was about once a month. The game is pretty short in length, so i advise that you play it infrequently; it isn't something you want to rush. Gris' story lacks dialogue completely, so everything is a guess and can be interpreted in many ways. What i believe it to be about i think is beautiful, for you it may be something different, either way, it is a very special experience. Once again i am blessed with a holy game that i frankly would've never found on my own, thank you, lord Cthulhu.

[b] Thank you to everyone who worked on this wonderful game [/b]

.......[b] and thank you! [/b]

139042772.review:
[h1]GRIS: Masterclass in Minimalism [/h1]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
Gris is a short but sweet platformer that takes minimalism to the extreme, both in artstyle and in gameplay. Luckily, unlike others in its genre, it manages to remain engaging the whole way through, all while remaining true to its choices. 
[hr][/hr]

[b]Review:[/b]
Although no-one can argue that they don’t look nice, in my opinion the formula for a genre I shall henceforth call the “journeylike” is both overdone and in need of a change. Many of these games attempt a minimalist approach to gameplay, often giving you one button to press in a world where movement is otherwise your only option. Perhaps this is to encourage players to focus on experiencing the world, but to me this approach to “gameplay” often greatly overstays its welcome in games like Abzu or Journey. This is the reason I avoided GRIS for so long. 

Although GRIS is certainly cut from the same cloth as the aforementioned titles, at least in my eyes, it achieves so much more. You start the game out with a tiny array of seemingly pointless abilities, but the lengths this game goes to use every single aspect of each one is to be commended. This game actually has puzzles, and although not overly complex, they kept me interested. Even as a self-professed hater of platformers, the relevant sections of GRIS were excellent, fluid, and surprisingly clear given the game’s art style. The secrets in this game are also so well hidden that they managed to keep me interested till long after the game had finished. 

If GRIS had just been a “journeylike” with more interesting gameplay, I would be happy, yet the title also artistically triumphs over its predecessors. The story told by GRIS is, at least to me, a lot more interesting than other games in its genre, even managing to use gameplay elements as metaphors on some occasions ([spoiler]I’m willing to bet the eel symbolizes rape[/spoiler]). In a stroke of genius, GRIS even weaponizes its own minimalism to achieve its own artistic goals – the most obvious case being [spoiler]the slow gain in color and visual complexity mirroring the character’s growth[/spoiler]. 

Indeed, there are remarkably few issues I have with GRIS, other than its obtuse menu navigation. Yet I still feel like this game is not yet the pinnacle of the “journeylike” genre. Although GRIS was an enjoyable, and sometimes powerful experience, the game was lacking memorability. The art style sometimes feels too “upmarket coffee shop”, the music, while beautiful, is generic, and few of the puzzles felt truly innovative. Perhaps, like the logo designers for all too many multinationals, GRIS’s pursuit of minimalism led to a purging of the qualities that might make it stand out more. GRIS is like a diamond polished to perfection: instead of retaining its character, it simply blends in with every other perfect diamond in the jewelry box. 
 
[h1]5/6[/h1]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/GentleHoovy/recommended/][b]More of my reviews here![/b][/url]

138944190.review:
GRIS is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. Not only because of the unique art style of Conrad Roset or the goosebump-inducing music by Berlinist, but also in the way that it can make you feel so many emotions, without a single word being spoken in the game. The art and the music complement each other extremely well and are likely to make you feel deep emotions.

The best way I can describe this game is a platformer with light puzzle elements that plays as if you are watching an animated movie. You're guiding this young girl Gris through her grieving process and all phases of grief are unique zones in the world. Denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance are all stages in the game that you have to play through and it's beautifully done. Each stage is recognizable as the theme of the world is adjusted to them.

The puzzles aren't very hard, so the game should be accessible for anyone regardless of skill level. But even if you are an experienced puzzler, this game is still completely worth it. It's an experience that I would recommend to anyone.

This game is unlike anything I've played before. It's a mesmerizing and beautiful experience... The music is really captivating, thrilling at times and just charming and atmospheric at others. The graphics are absolutely brilliant and so unique. It's my second playthrough of this game so I was doing it rather fast but I had to sit back at times just to admire the wonderful imagery again. 

I'm just a regular 18 year old boy, deeper meaning is something I rarely even think about in media. However Gris truley touched something inside of me emotionally wich I can't quite describe. There's strong themes of depression and grief which almost anyone can relate to at some capacity. Yet Gris truly conveys a different message for anyone who plays it. And I can't recommend it enough...

Gris is not just a game for me, I would rather call it a work of art.

138809032.review: Este juego fue para mí una plétora audiovisual, no es revolucionario por sus mecánicas, son iguales a las de cualquier juego de plataforma 2d, este juego tampoco tiene diálogos para contarte su historia, pero aun así se ha transformado en uno de mis juegos favoritos. Como dije, este juego no tiene una historia narrada, pero si tiene historia, una historia que viene de escuchar y de ver sus escenarios, este juego requiere si o si una interpretación del jugador, pero la única forma de entender es abriendo tu corazón a la historia, es un juego que solo se deja amar por aquellos que están dispuestos a dejarse amar primero, abriendo su corazón. No es un juego sobre el cual hacer miles de reflexiones y análisis filosóficos (aunque se pudieran hacer), es un juego que se entiende solo dejándose llevar por el ir y venir de sus colores y canciones, es un juego de perdición, destrucción y vacío, de la caída de un mundo ya construido, pero también es un juego de valentía, esperanza y creación sobre como recuperarte de algo que paso, aceptar tu pasado, perdonarte para que puedas seguir construyendo un futuro mejor. Gris me enseño cosas de cosas que pensé que ya sabia cuando en realidad no sabía nada, es la verdadera experiencia de recuperación, de un trauma del que ya no tienes ni voz para escuchar tu llanto, ni tus lamentos puedes musitar, pero aun así los ves y te pesan como una carga insoportable, pero Gris crece y tu junto a ella  y a medida que crecen, recuperan sus colores, no reconstruirse exactamente igual que antes, sino aceptando y volviendo al trauma y al dolor parte de ti, al fin podrás conseguir tu voz y cambiar tu percepción del mundo para volver a soñar con un mundo al que le puedes dar forma.

138366894.review:
Beautiful game and a beautiful soundtrack but no great gameplay and a pretty terrible story.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is a standard puzzle platformer but exceedingly easy. As the game progress, Gris unlocks different abilities that enhance the movement and add to the puzzles but it never gets very complex and the puzzles are easily solved and not challenging from the platforming aspect either. The movement feels ok, it can be a bit slow at times and the double jump is wonky. Another strange aspect of the gameplay is the water dash, for some reason, this ability feels off, it doesn’t seem to have the proper momentum or weight to it and it feels weird to use. There are many seeming paths that can be taken but they all lead the same way, the game is very linear with little room for deviation or side things. There are some mementos that can be obtained with some little side puzzles but these aren’t challenging either. There is basically no way to fail things in the game despite some sequences where it would make sense for this to be the case, this actually takes the player completely out of the game in one section as it is difficult to tell if what the player is doing is actually affecting the game at all.

[h1] Story [/h1]

The story is extremely minimal, it follows a girl(Gris) going through grief which has both literally and metaphorically drained the color from the world. Gris gains abilities as she restores color to the world and seeks to regain the ability to sing. There is no dialogue or text throughout the entire game and it is told through all pictures and some cutscenes, the problem is that non of this is very engaging, the game is essentially never played during the most important moments, the player will sit there and watch a cutscene of Gris doing something important. While this may work nicely in a short film, in a game it does not.


[h1] Graphics [/h1]

The art style is gorgeous, it is a 2d painted style with great animation work. As more and more color comes into the game it becomes even more pretty to look at as the environments for the most part are well-designed and have unique looks and feels to them. Almost every aspect of the game's art could be used as a good background or art piece and it is clear a lot of passion and work went into making the game look as unique and great as it does. Everything in Gris's meticulously designed environment works well in telling the story, it’s just a shame the story is so minimal and the gameplay is lacking.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]

The soundtrack is beautiful and goes hand in hand with the art style. Many of the pieces are gorgeous and convey many emotions with them whether it be an overwhelming sense of sorrow, pervasive darkness, or an accepting joy. Each piece feels distinct and captures the game so well.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Gris is a very strange game, on the one hand, both the gameplay and the story are lacking and make for an unenjoyable game experience. On the other hand, the art and soundtrack create a beautiful piece to listen to and look at. As such the game doesn’t work as a game.

[h1] Score: 4/10 [/h1]

138325531.review:
"A minimalist paradise with gorgeous use of color, excellent framing and music - For as cryptic and ambiguous as the story is, the game is still able to be enjoyed despite certain elements being a complete mystery. It not only has a fantastic visual style but it also has a fun moveset, it's refusal to have any tutorials beyond educating you on what buttons correspond to which moves makes solving puzzles feel satisfying. Though frustrating at points, I never felt cheated - the keys to advancing from one stage to another feel justified, I never felt as if it were the game's fault when I wasn't able to solve something right away. It has quite the considerable length, I did not pay for this game but I feel I would've gotten my money's worth even with its price. For as linear as the game is, it does a great job at making you feel as if the world you inhibit is a lot bigger than it likely is, there's considerably no loading screens between stages and it all meshes seamlessly as one giant level. Adding to this vastness is the game cleverly relying on objects to prevent you from going out of bounds rather than cheap invisible walls. Having extra collectibles out of reach not only adds to the vastness but also makes this game ripe for replay value. It has fantastic animation that feels buttery smooth and satisfying to control, this is Nomada Studios' first array into video games and it was a great display of their talent as animators and graphic designers. It looks beautiful, but upon playing it's a lot more than that - I'd highly recommend this game to people already sold on the art style as well as people that are into puzzle platformers."
- Reviewed by ScribbleTV

138325337.review:
This game is an unabashed experience. When the ending hit, I played through it again to study how nicely everything led to the ending. The symbolism of each chapter is an obvious yet subtle approach. I had an even greater appreciation of how much it told from the landscape and level design.

The designers did a fantastic job of ensuring time is well-spent when progressing. They also often allow for a relaxed pace to appreciate the scenery and music.

The mechanics are efficiently explained, staying consistent without forcing re-learning. The game only requires movement, jump, and two buttons with unobtrusive, clear situations. Minor challenge without distracting from the aesthetics, no extreme timing or precision required.

Gris is worth the time, telling its story in a convenient and delightful package. Enjoyable in a single afternoon and worth finishing in one go. Gris provides an emotional experience to anyone who can empathize with the ending. It pays off each step, feeling earned in its pleasant pacing.

138199238.review:
(Ignore the game time hours - I played most of it on Steam Deck, offline - it took me around 5 hours to complete)

Review:
The pure embodiment of 'show don't tell' storytelling, and this makes its way into gameplay also. No tutorials, no text, no arrows, guides, or speech. Only showing through little story moments for you to figure out.

Gameplay-wise, it's mostly a simple platformer with a few cute ideas. Gris's strength, however, lies in its atmosphere, environment and the bold choices it took with how it delivers the hero's emotional journey of dealing with loss, pain, the importance of embracing grief, and healing yourself.

It's a thing of beauty, a little journey and world you can get lost in for a few hours, built on the artistic representations of emotions, both positive and negative, depression, hope, and the power of memories.

138077272.review:
It's really not my thing. I like artsy games and all, but there's gotta be an actual[i] game [/i]in there for me to enjoy. And to me, Gris is not engaging. It's a lot of leaning waaaay back, holding left or right, and watching your character run through an environment, occasionally interrupted by cutscenes. The art is okay, and the music is nice and all, but it wasn't enough to keep me engaged. I probably didn't hang in long enough to really catch onto the plot, and sure it's my loss, but it never got me interested.

So if it fails as a game, does it succeed as a movie? Not really. You just watch a character walk through pretty landscapes, and sometimes she jumps around and uses a few abilities to solve super basic, linear puzzles. I was expecting more of a metroidvania-like experience, but this game is not that, and I just didn't vibe with what it ended up being.

UNA HERMOSA OBRA DE ARTE, un lienzo lleno de colores que no deja escapar ni un solo instante de nuestra atención para así transmitir decenas de emociones. I was very excited to play Gris. Unfortunately the game did not do it for me. 

Pros
- Good soundtrack
- Sweet moments and interactions with the creatures you meet in the game
- Interesting use of colors

Cons
- The music was decent, but very high pitched at some parts to the point where it was painful to listen to with headphones on
- The puzzles were very simplistic and short. There was very little challenge in the game
- The story was vague, and nothing is really answered after the game's completion

Throughout my entire play through, I felt like I was just waiting for the game to start. I didn't hate the game, but it's not what I was hoping it would be.

137795360.review:
A brief but beautiful walking sim / puzzler. The geometric environments are a delight to look at and the clever uses of sounds and color really make this vibrant world come to life. It's probably one of the most striking games I've ever seen.

I think it's worth to know beforehand the theme of Gris, as it gives you insight into the environments and what things mean, and that insight can make certain moments more emotional: it's about [spoiler]loss and the stages of grief[/spoiler].

The gameplay is simplistic but serves its purpose well enough. If you enjoy artistic games with wonderful soundtracks, you will probably like this.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]

137630943.review:
[h1] This is not a game intended to be played, but intended to be felt. [/h1]

[h3] From [/h3] the scenery to the details in the viuals to the charming melodies, eveything is made to make you [i] feel [/i] something, to make you understand what it is to go through the process of loss, all thanks to the subtlety of metaphors and other analogies. You're not there to have fun, you're there to unfold with care all the petals of every sequence of emotions someone has to pass through when something has been ripped away from them. 

If you're expecting a game to pass time, or a game to play, it's not it, not at all. The goal here is to let your emotional valves on, and to let the flow of emotions and feelings this game is trying to convey in. 

If you can do that, you'll go for a wonderful, sad, beautiful, and entirely humane experience. 

Note: Prepare some tissue for the ending if you're not emotionless towards beauty.

If you love the atmospheric storytelling and platforming puzzles in games such as Journey and Abzu, this game is worth your attention.

The watercolor art style is gorgeous and the choice in music is skillfully done. You can tell right away that this game was made with a lot of skill, attention and thought. There is a lot to be said about games as vehicles to experience art, and Gris is a shining example of how this is done well.

137530994.review:
TL;DR
A really good 4hr game, when I finally got to the credits I just sat back and watched feeling complete.

Playing this game is more akin to experiencing a great art piece instead of playing a game (in a good way).The platforming is great and doesn't slow down the pace. The visuals and music are amazing and really suck you into the game, making it easy to lose track of time. It took me around 4 hours to complete the first playthrough (I took my time and explored everything), but I'm definitely going to play it again and try to 100% it. I recommend not stressing out about finding everything on your first playthrough, because there's a chapter select once you beat the game. I suggest playing it all in one sitting with no distractions to get the full experience and feel accomplished when you get to the credits. (Full disclosure: I acquired the game while it was on sale)

137518196.review:
This is a masterpiece, the music, a painting you play; you are not watching a screen, you are painting, you are the painting.
The journey feels made of watercolors and star dust as much as it feels made of flesh and bones, emotions, wonder.
You will feel that wonder I can assure you, like when you experience something you have never felt before, not just never seen before, it's a synthetic journey that I wish to meet again when I sleep. I have been very pensive during Gris, I have been healing I think, this game heals anything. I have heard of this masterpiece some time ago and never installed it or pressed play as I want try to start stories one by one without leaving too many books open... you know what I mean, and this is an experience I finished, and I was regretting it was finished, or in other words I would love to see more one day. It took 4.9 hours, with only one initial (red baloon) "stuck" moment where I decided to start the game again. The game is so relaxing you will feel the music is playing inside you.
Gris seems to massage your solitude, it makes you smile. I smiled several times, not a sad or nostalgic smile, but an enthusiast happiness, and in a final part near the end it was like a crescendo a ladder of smile, so much I said, "how much more is it going to surprise me, it always finds a new way to do that".

This game is sincere art. When the pro get to it.

I don't like to mention other games if this feels like an offense, I just do it as a suggestion and to make understand my perspectives to others and well, this is a "beyond game" as I call these type of masterpieces, and it goes along with HellBlade Senua's Sacrifice and I think also Never Alone. If you check what these games are, you will understand.

Buy this game, gift this game, play it with someone else you love or to feel something together, talk about this unique "beyond-game".

Use headphones and I suggest playing with a joypad. (I used the ps4 one)
I really rarely replay games, actually never. This is one of very few ones I would play again.
I hope Devolver Digital or others will help these creators bring something else to life in the future. Thank you.

Ciao.

137517003.review:
I appreciate GRIS as a work of art, very beautiful and atmospheric.
I can't stand it as a game, though. 
The movement (running around) felt rather tedious and slow. There were no directions or rewind/reload control (so easy to miss a collectible area), and game was hard on readability (sometimes unclear what is foreground, gameplay zone, or background).

And then there's the subpar platforming experience. The collision felt poor. Usually good platformers have a "grace" system that allows to jump and land from air close to edge of a platform. In GRIS it was the opposite, I'd fallen from platforms I should have stayed at. And there is a lot of jumping.

The puzzles were okay. The timed platforming sequences (disappearing cubes) was the moment where I asked myself, if I want to continue this "experience". And the answer was a resounding No.

I was going to give this a thumbs up for the art. But writing this review, I realize I did not enjoy that hour of play, and would not want to recommend friends to *play* it. So, thumbs sideways, but mostly down.

This a work of art, but not in the right medium for it.

137397300.review:
Gris chooses to tell its story almost in the style of interpretive dance. There are no words or dialogue. Nothing but weeping statues and body language to give a broader context to the series of platforming puzzles ahead of you. The music and watercolor art design are left to do the rest.

And what a wonderful job they do! The swelling of strings, both vocal and instrumental, never fail to intensify the sense of depth and scale. While paint bleeding through the hard lines of the environment keeps the experience ethereal and otherworldly. It's all so haunting in a way that never seeks to explain itself. 

There is, however, a bit of background to be found in the game's achievements. But you won't have to fight too hard to complete them either. The only challenge Gris seems interested in is the emotional one at its core.

Beautiful visuals, superb animations and outstanding music; GRIS is an astounding experience.

GRIS focuses on a young woman who has lost someone and is going through the stages of grief within her own mind. Whether that someone is a friend, sister or lover is never revealed but that doesn't really matter; she is clearly of great importance to the protagonist.

The game itself is a 2D platformer with light puzzling. The mechanics could have been deeper but what exists adequately serves the purpose of the game.

GRIS provokes sorrow that cuts to the core, and has a beauty that touches the heart. You may even shad a few tears. It's a short experience but one that is well worth your time.

137216236.review: a game with outstanding music and artwork that tells the story of a young girl navigating through the stages of grief using only the environment and actions to tell the story instead of words. the game mechanics are fairly easy with the occasional puzzles to advance to the next section. there is no guidance or indication of what to do and leaves it to the player to find out what to do, which felt intentional for the immersion of this girl's story. i was mostly confused at the early parts of the game but once it hit, i was in shambles. overall it is an amazing game that i would 100% recommend for a good story.

137184551.review: Lovely game ♥ stunning visuals, artsy design, and soothing music created such a calming and relaxing atmosphere. Every new chapter, you learned new abilities that kept the gameplay fresh and exciting. Colorful world of GRIS was truly a joy to explore. [b] Highly recommend! [/b]

137180316.review:
GRIS is a short but gorgeous cozy-game. You start in a black and white world and gain a new colour with each chapter. That was all I knew about the game when I started playing it.
Little did I know how deep the story truly is. It was only until I searched for the achievements mid game that I understood what this game is truly about: The stages of grief.
Each colour represents a stage and oh boy, combining the psychology behind it with the beautiful artstyle shows, how much love to the detail the creators put into this game. The complexity behind everything is stunning.
I recommend watching this YouTube video, it explains all those details very well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-UD-aW2tpg

But speaking of the gameplay now: GRIS surely is a cozy game, a platformer that allows you to relax and dive into another world. At some points it might feel like a walking simulator, as there are some passages in which you are just running, but they don't last long enough to disturb your gaming experience, wanting to smash more buttons. While running you can also enjoy the view and it makes sense regarding the grief to have such passages. The jumping und puzzling parts don't come too short, don't worry about that. With each level you gain a new ability to get to new areas.
While I was playing, I feared to miss out some parts, being the discoverer and achievement hunter I am, as I had to choose which way to go. That led to some missed collectibles, but after finishing the game you can select each chapter again to find them. I like the achievements you can get, especially the one with the apples, and it is easy to gain 100%.
I really recommend GRIS to any platform lover, anyone who appreciates well thought out games and enjoys a unique artstyle.

137177007.review: Simply a stunning work of art, with a poignant emotional aspect.

137135724.review:
Si estas pasando por el duelo de haber perdido a un ser querido y estas luchando contra esos sentimientos encontrados dentro tuyo que quieren hacerte correr, gritar, llorar, esta obra audiovisual puede significar mucho para vos como lo hizo en mi.
El simbolismo de las mecánicas de lo visual y de la banda sonora juegan un papel importante en la narrativa de esta historia tan endulzante como trágica. Gris se volvió en tan solo 2 horas uno de mis videojuegos favoritos y me hizo llorar desde principio a fin con la increíble armonía de todos sus componentes.
Si estas pensando comprarte este juego, deja de pensarlo y hacelo, no vas a perder tu tiempo.

Por razones como estas los videojuegos son Arte.

137095742.review:
I played this originally on the PlayStation 4, and I got the platinum for it. I wanted to support the developers of the game, so I purchased it on multiple platforms (Nintendo Switch, PS4, and the Play Store, and now on Steam), and because the PlayStation 4 does not have written reviews, I came to voice my opinion here:

What a fun and enjoyable, relaxing experience! This is not a game; this is a masterpiece. It's like you're playing and moving throughout a painting, and the soundtrack merges so well with the art design, which is really beautiful. If I could capture every frame of this game and print it and hang it on my wall, I would do it without any hesitation, and the story of this game is told without saying a single word, breaking every linguistic barrier, so no matter what languages you speak, you would understand the story. The game is not too long; you can complete it with every achievement in about 5 hours. I would recommend you play it without any interruptions, and I would recommend you play it with your headphones on just to enjoy the soundtrack. I will never forget this game.

137084801.review:
Una obra de arte hecha juego.

La estetica, los escenarios, la musica, los puzzles... todo en este juego esta hecho con mucho mimo y cariño, cuidando hasta el minimo detalle. Merece la pena jugarlo para cambiar un poco la idea de que el concepto del juego es subrir porque es complicado, aqui solo tienes que disfrutar de la experiencia que te puede presentar verlo.

El juego en si no es dificil, los puzzles y las plataformas son faciles de completar. Yo creo que el juego esta más pensado en disfrutar de las imagenes más que te pueda presentar como un reto.

137073862.review:
Ok, this is going to be difficult, but i personally would not recommend Gris.
However, if you try the game for yourself, don't read the steam description, don't read up on any story or achievements, just [i] go in blind and experience it [/i], 
like a playable movie and make your own assumptions about the meaning of the game; you'll get much more enjoyment out of it this way. 
Don't rush it and just take in the art & music.

[u]Pros: [/u]
+Amazing sound design: 
     Soundtrack, sound effects, ambient sounds, mixing. Put on good headphones with decent bass and enjoy.
+Artstyle and graphics
     Very abstract, but coherent and beautiful artstyle with a interesting usage of colour.
+(relativly) stress-free
     Explore the (linear) world at your own pace; no death, no timer, basically like reading a book.


[u]Cons: [/u]
-Story and intent
(There will be minor spoilers starting here, so i will hide spoiler-relevant parts.)
 I tried to like this game. I really tried. 
I kind of enjoyed the first playthrough. I made a second playthrough to get all achievments and it was ok. 
I made a slow third playthrough to really take in the world and the story and i disliked it, a lot.

The word that kept creeping up in my mind was [i] pretentious [/i] 
The game trys so hard to be inspiring, to be deep and philosophical, to be artsy. 
The game starts with a cutscene and 15 seconds later there are the names of the lead designer and lead producer, proudly displayed in the middle, like a David Cage game. You play for another minute and there is a cutscene only for the title of the game. ok....
If you had absolutly no idea about the story, then you can make up your own mind. Is it about depression? Maybe a fractured self? Or interactions between the protagonist and the world? Or something else entirely?
[spoiler] Nope, it's about grief after the loss of her mother and [i] only [/i] that. 
It's a premise, that was explored in countless other media, be it books, movies or songs. The developer made sure that you get that on their steam description. Major achievments are literally named after the five stages of grief and the whole game tries to replicate those five stages of grief.  [/spoiler]
It would be fine, if it was the backstory for one character among many, to serve as a catalyst for the story, but as a whole game i don't think it works.

Maybe the overwhelming praise from the positive steam reviews set up false expectations, but the core of the game is one single premise, a sorrowful one, but also a common one.

137029866.review:
It's a lovely short game about the grief in the wake of loosing a loved one, in this case a mother. The game takes the protagonist through the 5 stages of grief and eventually finding peace. Definitely worth a try!

136982114.review:
Beautiful game with some minor flaws.
First of all, this game is very much worth playing for the artstyle and music alone. I highly recommend it. 
The gameplay is decent with 2 or 3 standout moments. 

I have 2 problems with the game: 
1. The game doesn't explain anything to you outside of the level design, so figuring out the next destination and learning how certain abilities worked was a bit confusing/frustrating sometimes. 
2. There's a "secret ending" that you unlock by collecting all mementos. I didn't do that and sadly that ending gives a ton of context and basically explains core elements of the game. Since I didn't know about the secret ending and don't usually hunt down all collectibles, I was lucky to learn about it after finishing the game and looked it up on YT.

[b]So if you play this, either make sure to collect all mementos or to watch the secret ending on YT once you finish the game. [/b]

136971226.review:
This isn't really a video game.  I'd say it's art, but that doesn't quite capture it.  This is a work of humanity - perhaps that's really the only descriptor you can offer it.

No review I can offer will ever do this game justice because what the visuals, music, and story express cannot be captured in words.  It's tangible emotion.  Stop wasting time trying to grok the meaning from others and just FEEL this.

136964482.review:
One of the best puzzle platformers I've played. Absolutely worth the price in my opinion. 

The game's visuals are beautiful in service to it's deep symbolism, dealing with topics such as loss, grief, and depression. If you want a long game with tons of combat, voiced characters, or deep lore, this isn't that. Instead, Gris (Gray) presents a stunning and somber world that you can feel as well as see. The musical score accentuates the gameplay perfectly, and it's watercolor style art leaves one in awe of the scenery.
